File.Title: A Cholinergic Projection to the Rat Superior Colliculus Demonstrated by Retrograde Transport of Horseradish Peroxidase and Choline Acetyltransferase Immunohistochemistry

Abstract.S: Acetylcholinesterase (AChE) has been localized by histochemistry in the superior colliculus and in the tegmentum of the caudal midbrain and rostra1 pons of the rat.
The pattern of AChE localization in the superior colliculus was characterized by homogeneous staining in the superficial layers and patchlike staining in the intermediate gray layer.

In the tegmentum, AChE was localized in the pedunculopontine nucleus (PPN), beginning rostrally at the caudal pole of the substantia nigra and extending caudally to the level of the parabrachial nuclei, and in the lateral dorsal tegmental nucleus (LDTN) of the central gray.

The localization of AChE in these nuclei overlapped the distribution of neurons stained by immunohistochemistry using an antibody to choline acetyltransferase (ChAT), the synthesizing enzyme of the neurotransmitter acetylcholine.
Other neighboring areas that were stained with AChE, but that did not contain ChAT-immunoreactive neurons, included the microcellular tegmental nucleus and the ventral tegmental nucleus.

Neurons in the PPN and LDTN were determined to be potential sources of the cholinergic projection to the intermediate gray layer of the rat superior colliculus by double labelling with retrograde transport of horseradish peroxidase (HRP) combined with the immunohistochemical localization of ChAT.
Three populations of neurons were identified.
A predominantly ipsilateral ChAT-immunoreactive population was located in the pars compacta subdivision of PPN (PPNpc).

Retrograde HRP-labelled neurons in the pars dissipata subdivison of the PPN (PPNpd), located ventral to the superior cerebellar peduncle (SCP) at the level of the inferior colliculus, composed a second population that was predominantly contralateral but was not ChAT immunoreactive.
A third population of retrogradely labelled neurons was predominantly ipsilateral and ChAT immunoreactive and was located in the LDTN.

These findings compared favorably with the full extent of the projection from this tegmental region revealed by retrograde transport of HRP from the superior colliculus when more compatible fixation and chromogen procedures were used.
The results suggest that the PPN and the LDTN are two sources of the cholinergic input to the superior colliculus.

Since the PPN also has extensive efferent, and afferent, connections with basal-ganglia-related structures, this cholinergic excitatory input to the superior colliculus, like the GABAergic inhibitory input from the substantia nigra pars reticulata, may provide the basis for an additional influence of the basal ganglia on visuomotor behavior.

Introduction.S: Histochemical studies have demonstrated a laminar-specific staining pattern of acetylcholinesterase in the superior colliculus in a variety of species (Shute and Lewis, '67; Graybiel, '78a, '79; Harvey and MacDonald, '85; Illing and Graybiel, '85).

The distribution of AChE in the superior colliculus is similar in all species, being characterized by homogeneous staining in the superficial layers and periodic bands or patches in the intermediate layer that are most Drominent in the caudal one-half of the colliculus.

The superior colliculus is known to have laminar-specific afferent and efferent connections (see Huerta and Harting, '84, for review), The staining pattern of AChE in the superior colliculus may be related to these connections.

It is unclear, however, whether the source of AChE staining in the superior colliculus is from intrinsic or extrinsic neurons, since the histochemical procedure for the localization of the enzyme does not distinguish between neurons that are cholinergic and/or cholinoceptive.

The laminar pattern Of AChE staining in the Superior COlliCUlUS is, therefore, possibly attributable to cholinoceptive neurons and/or to the synaptic termination Of extrinsic cholinergic neurons that project to the superior colliculus.
The brainstem has 10% been considered the major Source of AChE in the intermediate layer of the superior colliculus.
Lesions of the midbrain tegmentum, in particular, have Produced decreased levels of AChE in the rat superior COllicuh3 (Shute and Lewis, '67; Hoover and Jacobowitz, '79).

Key words: pedunculopontine tegmental nucleus (Ch5), lateral dorsal tegmental Histochemical studies have demonstrated a laminar-specific staining pattern of acetylcholinesterase in the superior colliculus in a variety of species (Shute and Lewis, '67; Graybiel, '78a, '79; Harvey and MacDonald, '85; Illing and Graybiel, '85).

The distribution of AChE in the superior colliculus is similar in all species, being characterized by homogeneous staining in the superficial layers and periodic bands or patches in the intermediate layer that are most Drominent in the caudal one-half of the colliculus.

The superior colliculus is known to have laminar-specific afferent and efferent connections (see Huerta and Harting, '84, for review), The staining pattern of AChE in the superior colliculus may be related to these connections.

It is unclear, however, whether the source of AChE staining in the superior colliculus is from intrinsic or extrinsic neurons, since the histochemical procedure for the localization of the enzyme does not distinguish between neurons that are cholinergic and/or cholinoceptive.

The laminar pattern Of AChE staining in the Superior COlliCUlUS is, therefore, possibly attributable to cholinoceptive neurons and/or to the synaptic termination Of extrinsic cholinergic neurons that project to the superior colliculus.
horseradish peroxidase (HRP) combined with CUT immunohistochemistry.

The findings indicate that a major source of the cholinergic afferent projection to the superior colliculus arises from a collection of neurons in the caudal midbrain and rostra1 pons that corresponds, at least in part, to the pedunculopontine tegmental nucleus and the lateral dorsal tegmental nucleus (Olszewski and Baxter, '541, or cholinergic cell groups Ch5 and Ch6 of Mesulam et al., ('83, '84).

Several sources of brainstem afferents to the superior colliculus terminate in the intermediate and deep layers in a AChE and HRP histochemistry patchlike fashion similar me to the distribution of AChE.

These fixative solution consisted of 1.0% paraformaldehyde Several sources of brainstem afferents to the superior colliculus terminate in the intermediate and deep layers in a patchlike fashion similar to the distribution of AChE.

These include the substantia nigra, the trigeminal complex7 the pretectum, the the nucleus of the Posterior commissure, the dorsal nucleus of the lateral lemniscus, the inferior colliculus, the deep nuclei of the cerebellum, the lateral cervical nucleus, and the spinal cord (Huerta and Harting, '84).
Projections from the substantia nigra and frontal cortex furthermore converge On the Patches of high AChE activity in the intermediate gray layer (Illing and Graybiel, '85).

In addition, several afferent structures demonstrate AChE-positive staining including the substantia nigra, the locus coeruleus, the pedunculopontine tegmental nucleus, the lateral dorsal tegmental nucleus, and the trigeminal complex (Shute and Lewis, '67; Satoh et al., '83; Butcher and WoOlf, '84; Smith and Parent, '84; Wilson, '85).

Based on ChAT immunoreactivity, however, only the pedunculopontine tegmental nucleus and the lateral dorsal tegmental nucleus appear to be cholinergic (Kimura et al., '81, '84; Amstrong et al., '83; Mesulam et al., '83, '84; Satoh and Fibiger, '85a,b).

These nuclei, therefore, may be sources of cholinergic input to the superior colliculus and may be at least partially responsible for the patchlike AChE staining pattern in the intermediate layer of this structure.

For the histochemical commissure, the dorsal nucleus of the lateral lemniscus, loca~ization of AChE, a modification of the copper thimhothe inferior colliculus, the deep nuclei of the cerebellum, line technique cewis and Shute, '66) was employed with the lateral cervical nucleus, and the spinal cord (Huerta acetylthiocholine iodide (Sigma) as the substrate and and Harting, '84).

Projections from the substantia nigra tetrai~opropy~pyrophosphoramide (isO-o~p~, 10-5 M; and frontal cortex furthermore converge On the Patches of Sigma) as an inhibitor of nonspecific (pseudo-, butmi-) high AChE activity in the intermediate gray layer (Illing and Graybiel, '85).

In addition, several afferent structures demonstrate AChE-positive staining including the substantia nigra, the locus coeruleus, the pedunculopontine tegmental nucleus, the lateral dorsal tegmental nucleus, and the trigeminal complex (Shute and Lewis, '67; Satoh et al., '83; Butcher and WoOlf, '84; Smith and Parent, '84; Wilson, '85).

Based on ChAT immunoreactivity, however, only the pedunculopontine tegmental nucleus and the lateral dorsal tegmental nucleus appear to be cholinergic (Kimura et al., '81, '84; Amstrong et al., '83; Mesulam et al., '83, '84; Satoh and Fibiger, '85a,b).

These nuclei, therefore, may be sources of cholinergic input to the superior colliculus and may be at least partially responsible for the patchlike AChE staining pattern in the intermediate layer of this structure.

The Present study has examined the localization and distribution Of cholinergic brainstem afferent neurons to the rat superior colliculus labelled by retrograde transport of tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) as the chromogen.
Following the reaction with hydrogen peroxide, sections were washed in acetate buffer, placed on pretreated microscope slides, counterstained with neutral red, dehydrated, and mounted with Permount.
Sections were examined and photographed by light microscopy with brightfield and darkfield illumination.
The locations of retrogradely labelled neurons were charted by using a microcomputer-controlled digitizer (Minnesota Datametrics) connected to the X and Y stage axes of a light microscope.
The locations of labelled neurons were determined by reference to the atlas of Paxinos and Watson ('82), with additional descriptions provided by Paxinos and Butcher ('85).
ChAT immunohistochemistry
The fixative solution consisted of 2.0% paraformaldehyde and 0.1% glutaraldehyde (TAAB) in 0.1 M phosphate buffer with 0.002% calcium chloride, pH 7.2.

Alternate sections first were processed for the histochemical demonstration of retrogradely transported HRP by incubation for 10-15 minutes in 0.05% diaminobenzidine tetrahydrochloride (DAB; Fluka) and 0.01% hydrogen peroxide containing 0.005% cobalt acetate and 0.005% nickel chloride in 0.1 M sodium phosphate buffer, pH 7.2.
This chromogen produced a black granular reaction product.

After washing through several changes of 0.1 M sodium phosphate buffer over 4-18 hours, sections were processed for the immunohistochemical localization of ChAT by using a rat monoclonal antibody (Boehringer-Mannheim) prepared from a rat-mouse hybridoma (Eckenstein and Thoenen, '82).

Sections were immersed for 1 hour in 10% normal rabbit serum (NRS) in phosphatebuffered saline (0.01 M; PBS) containing 0.3% Triton X-100 and then incubated in primary antibody (1:4 dilution; 2 pgl ml) containing 1% NRS and 0.1% Triton X-100 in PBS for 18-24 hours at 4Â°C with constant agitation.
As a control, some sections were incubated in the same solution without the addition of primary antibody.

After incubation, sections were washed for 30 minutes in three changes of PBS and immersed in biotinylated anti-rat IgG (1:200; Vector) in PBS with 1% NRS for 90 minutes at room temperature with constant agitation.
Following the secondary antibody incubation, sections were washed in PBS and immersed in an avidin:biotinylated horseradish peroxidase complex (ABC, Vector; 1:lOO) for 90 minutes.
Sections then were washed through three changes of PBS over 30 minutes followed by two changes of 0.1 M Tris-HC1 buffer, pH 7.6, for 20 minutes.
For the demonstration of HRP, sections were immersed in 0.05% DAB (Polysciences) and 0.01% hydrogen peroxide in 0.1 M Tris-HC1 buffer, pH 7.6, for 1015 minutes.
This chromogen produced a brown diffuse reaction product.

Sections were rinsed through several changes of 0.1 M Tris-HC1 buffer, washed overnight in 0.1 M sodium phosphate buffer, and then placed on pretreated microscope slides, dehydrated, and mounted with Permount.
Untreated adjacent sections also were placed on pretreated slides and counterstained with cresyl violet to provide a reference for the cytoarchitedural localization of the labelled neurons.

Sections were examined and photographed by light microscopy with brightfield illumination, and the locations of single-labelled (immunoreactive ChAT or retrograde HRP) or double-labelled (CUT and HRP) neurons were charted as described above.

Results.S: RESULTS
Distribution of AChE
The distribution of AChE in the superior colliculus of the rat was similar to that described previously in a variety of species (Shute and Lewis, '67; Graybiel, '78a, '79; Harvey and MacDonald, '85).
Dense homogeneous staining characterized the neuropil of the superficial layer, extending from the stratum zonale to the ventral border of the stratum griseum superficiale (Fig. 1B).
In the stratum griseum intermediale, AChE was present throughout much of the rostral-caudal extent of the superior colliculus, but was more intense in the caudal half.

At this location, the AChE staining exhibited the characteristic patchlike distribution with transverse bands following the dorsal and ventral margins of the intermediate gray layer, interconnected by radially oriented columns (Fig. 1B).
The ventral band and radial columns had a coarse appearence that was more consistent with axonal labelling.
The transverse bands of AChE staining occupied the entire mediolateral extent of the intermediate gray, being wider laterally and narrower and more intense medially (Fig. 1B).

The ventral band of AChE staining overlapped the distribution of large neurons that characterize this region of the intermediate gray layer in Nissl-stained sections (Fig. 1A) and appeared to highlight the apparent absence of staining in the stratum griseum profundum.
The stratum opticum also was devoid of AChE staining.

Shute and Lewis ('67) speculated that the AChE staining in the superior colliculus was attributable to cholinergic derents and that the source of this input was the AChEstained pedunculopontine nucleus (PPN).
In the present study, AChE-stained neurons were located in the PPN, as well as in the lateral dorsal tegmental nucleus (LDTN), throughout their rostral-caudal extent.
Other neighboring structures also displayed AChE staining, including the parabigeminal nucleus, the microcellular tegmental nucleus, and the ventral tegmental nucleus (Fig. 2A-C).
In these regions, however, the pattern of staining appeared to be associated with axons and the neuropil.
The specificity of AChE staining in the superior colliculus, and in the PPN and LDTN, was demonstrated in control sections processed for the histochemical localization of BuChE.
In these sections, staining was completely absent, indicating that the AChE localization was not attributable to the hydrolysis of the substrate by nonspecific (or pseudo-) cholinesterase.
Location and extent of HRP injections

TTE.S: In experiments in which the superior colliculus was injected with HRP, sections were processed by using DAB as the chromogen to determine the location of the injection site and the potential extent of effective uptake.

In order to counteract the reduced enzyme activity with paraformaldehyde fixation and the lower sensitivity of the DAB chromogen in detecting HRP-labelled neurons, injections in experiments processed for immunohistochemistry were larger than those that were used for retrograde labelling with TMB as the chromogen.
All but two injections were centered in the intermediate layer of the superior colliculus.

The injections were positioned at various levels throughout the rostral-caudal extent of the superior colliculus and usually involved spread tothe superficial layers but did not extend beyond the deep layers (Fig. 1C).
These experiments produced moderate to dense retrograde labelling of neurons in the PPN and LDTN, the number of which appeared to be correlated with the sue of the injection site.

In two other experiments, in which the injection was confined primarily to the superficial layers with only slight spread into the intermediate layers, dense retrograde labelling of neurons was observed in the contralateral parabigeminal nucleus.
Neurons in the PPN and LDTN, however, were only sparsely and lightly labelled in these experiments.

Results.S: Distribution of retrograde HRP-labelled and/or CUT-immunoreactive neurons

In sections processed for the colocalization of ChAT and retrogradely transported HRP, the distribution of ChATimmunoreactive neurons was similar to that described previously (Armstrong et al., '83; Mesulam et al., '83).

ChATimmunoreactive neurons, identified on the basis of a diffuse brown staining of the soma and dendrites, first appeared rostrally at the level of the trochlear nucleus, dorsolateral to the most caudal extent of the substantia nigra and ventromedial to the parabigeminal nucleus (Figs. 2D, 3A).
This most rostral portion of the cell group corresponds to the pars dissipata subdivision of the pedunculopontine tegmental nucleus (PPNpd), as described by Olszewski and Baxter ( 54).
Further caudally, this ChAT-immunoreactive cell group migrates dorsomedially to eventually surround the superior cerebellar peduncle (SCP) at the level of the midinferior colliculus (Figs. 2E, 3D).
The dense cluster of ChATimmunoreactive neurons lateral to the SCP at this level corresponds to the pars compacta subdivision of the pedunculopontine nucleus (PPNpc; Olszewski and Baxter, 54).
The ring of ChAT-immunoreactive neurons that circumscribes the SCP at this level is completed dorsomedially by the ChAT-immunoreactive LDTN (Fig. 2E).

The immunoreactive neurons of the PPN extend further caudally into the rostral pons where, at the level of the lateral and medial parabrachial nuclei, the PPNpd is medial to the SCP and extends dorsomedially into the subcoeruleus region to become contiguous with the LDTN (Figs. 2F, 3F).
ChAT-immunoreactive neurons of the LDTN occupy the entire rostral-caudal extent of the nucleus, extending as far caudally as the locus coeruleus and the trigeminal motor nucleus (Figs.
ZF, 3H).
The locations of ChAT-immunoreactive neurons in the PPN and the LDTN correspond to the cholinergic cell groups Ch5 and Ch6 of Mesulam et al. ( 83, 84).
Neurons that were both ChAT-immunoreactive and labelled retrogradely with HRP were found throughout the region of the PPN and the LDTN.

These neurons were identified on the basis of the presence of immunoreactive staining that appeared as diffuse brown soma-dendritic staining of the cell with distinct black granules distributed throughout the soma attributable to the retrograde transport of HRP (Fig. 4A,B).
In the rostral portion of the PPNpd, a few double-labelled neurons were found bilaterally (Fig. 3A,B).
At caudal midbrain levels, double-labelled neurons were found bilaterally in the PPNpc with ipsilateral predominance (Fig. 3C,D).
While the majority of double-labelled neurons were found in the PPNpc, a few were scattered in the PPNpd bilaterally throughout the rostralcaudal extent of this cell group.
Numerous ChAT-immunoreactive neurons of the LDTN were also labelled with retrogradely transported HRP.
These neurons were present bilaterally with a marked ipsilateral predominance (Fig. 3D-F).
Double-labelled neurons of the LDTN were located primarily in the rostral portion of the nucleus.
Some neurons of the PPN were labelled only with retrogradely transported HRP, which appeared as black granules in the cytoplasm of the nonimmunoreactive soma (Fig. 4C).
A prominent cluster of these HRP-labelled neurons was located in the caudal midbrain ventral to the SCP in the contralateral PPNpd (Fig. 3D,E).
A similar group of tightly clustered neurons was present on the ipsilateral side, but these were only lightly labelled.
Other retrograde HRP singly labelled neurons were found scattered throughout the region of the PPN but were few in number and were present primarily at the level of the rostral pons.

Neurons of the PPN and LDTN that were ChAT-immunoreactive and HRP-labelled and those ventral to the SCP labelled only with retrogradely transported HRP could be distinguished from each other on the basis of their distinct soma-dendritic morphologies.
The ChAT-immunoreactive neurons of the PPN were multipolar with dendrites that gradually emerged from the soma, thus producing an irregular appearance (Fig. 4B).
The ChAT-immunoreactive neurons of the LDTN, by contrast, had a circular or oval appearance with dendrites that emerged abruptly from the Soma (Fig. 4A).

The neurons located in the region ventral to the SCP, which were labelled only with retrogradely transported HRP, displayed a characteristic slender fusiform profile whose plane of elongation was parallel to the trajectory of axons that composed the SCP (Fig. 4 0 A single dendrite usually emanated gradually from each pole of the soma.
Distribution of retrograde HRP-labelled neurons with TMB as chromogen

In order to determine the full extent of the projection to the superior colliculus from the region of the PPN and LDTN, sections were processed with TMB as the chromogen for the localization of retrogradely transported HRP.
The following description of the pattern of labelled neurons is limited to this region and adjacent nuclei.
It is not intended to be a complete description of the brainstem afferents to the rat superior colliculus.

TTE.S: Injections of HRP centered in the intermediate gray layer of the superior colliculus produced extensive retrograde labelling of neurons in the rostral portion of the substantia nigra pars reticulata (Fig. 6A).
In the same experiments, HRP-labelled neurons in the PPNpd first appeared bilaterally dorsolateral to the caudal extent of the substantia nigra at the level of the trochlear nucleus.
The full extent of the ipsilateral neuronal labelling could not be determined because of heavy fiber labelling.

At this level, the labelled neuronsof the PPNpd were medial to the labelled neurons of the paralemniscal nuclei, and were bounded dorsolaterally by the parabigeminal nucleus and dorsomedially by the nucleus cuneiformis (Figs. 5A-C, 6B).
Because of involvement of the superficial layers at the injection site, neuronal labelling in the parabigeminal nucleus was bilateral with a marked contralateral predominance.
Bilateral neuronal labelling was also present throughout the nucleus cuneiformis (Figs. 5A, B, 6B).
At levels through the rostral one-third of the inferior colliculus, the labelled neurons of the PPNpd assumed a position more medial and dorsal in the tegmentum.

At this level the PPNpd was clearly segregated from the laterally located nuclei of the lateral lemniscus and the dorsally located nucleus cuneiformis, both of which also contained labelled neurons bilaterally.
The ipsilateral fiber labelling that obscured labelled neurons at more rostral levels decreased, and an ipsilateral predominance of labelled neurons in the PPNpd was apparent (Figs. 5D, 6C,D).
Labelled neurons of the PPNpc were present lateral to the SCP at the mid-inferior colliculus level with a definite ipsilateral predominance (Fig. 5D,E).
Scattered labelled neurons were also present in the PPNpd dorsal and ventral to the SCP with a prominent cluster of neurons located just ventral to the SCP contralaterally (Figs. 5E,F, 6C,D).

From the level of the caudal inferior colliculus to the rostral pons at the level of the parabrachial nuclei, labelled neurons of PPN gradually became confined to the region ventromedial to the SCP, just lateral to the central gray with a continued ipsilateral predominance (Fig. 5H-4.
In the central gray, labelled neurons were found in the dorsal nucleus of the raphe, particularly in its rostral portion.
The lateral dorsal tegmental nucleus also contained HRP-labelled neurons throughout its rostral-caudal extent with a marked ipsilateral predominance (Fig. 5E-4.
The LDTN extended more caudally in the brainstem than the PPN, ending at the level of the rostral trigeminal motor nucleus and locus coeruleus.

Results.S: The distributions and types of neurons that were retrogradely labelled in these areas were similar to those that had been identified in the immunohistochemical experiments (Fig. 4D-F).
The characteristic fusiform shape of the contralateral neurons ventral to the SCP, in particular, was accentuated by the extensive soma-dendritic labelling produced by the TMB chromogen (Fig. 4F).

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION
This study identifies the pedunculopontine tegmental (PPN) and the lateral dorsal tegmental (LDTN) nuclei as sources of the cholinergic projection to the rat superior colliculus.
A cholinergic input to the superior colliculus has been suspected on the basis of its AChE activity (Shute and Lewis, '67; Graybiel, '78a, '79; Harvey and MacDonald, '85).

Regions of the brainstem caudal to the superior colliculus have been considered to be the source of this innervation since lesions of the midbrain tegmentum have produced decreased levels of AChE and ChAT in the intermediate gray layer (Shute and Lewis, '67; Hoover and Jacobowitz, '79).
In the present study, bilateral labelling of ChAT-immunoreactive neurons was observed in the rostra1 portion of the PPNpd beginning at the level of the trochlear nucleus.

At the midlevel of the inferior colliculus, where the pars compacta portion of PPN is located lateral to the SCP, neurons projecting the superior colliculus were labelled bilaterally with an ipsilateral predominance.
Most of the retrograde HRP-labelled neurons in the PPNpc were ChATimmunoreactive.
At this level, the neurons of the PPNpd were also labelled bilaterally with a contralateral predominance, including a prominent cluster of noncholinergic neurons located ventral to the SCP.
All of the neurons of the LDTN that were labelled with retrograde HRP were also ChAT-immunoreactive but were predominantly ipsilateral.
Other studies also have implicated the region of the PPN as a source of subcortical afferents to the superior colliculus in the cat (Graybiel, '77, '78b; Edwards et al., '79).
Edwards et al. ('79) referred to the PPN as the parabrachial nuclei, which were labelled bilaterally without note of any ipsilatera1 or contralateral predominance.
Autoradiographic studies of the efferent projections of the PPN, however, have demonstrated only sparse labelling in the superior colliculus (Graybiel, '77; Moon-Edley and Graybiel, '83).
This may be due to the fact that the injections in these studies were discrete and did not involve a large number of neurons in this region that project to the superior colliculus.

In order to visualize the full extent of this projection, injections would have to involve every level of the PPN since, as demonstrated in the present study, neurons of the PPN that project to the superior colliculus are widely distributed throughout the rostral-caudal extent of the nucleus.

The predominantly ipsilateral projection from the LDTN and projections from the nucleus cuneiformis, dorsal raphe nucleus, and dorsal nucleus of the lateral lemniscus, as observed in the present study, have also been previously noted (Edwards et al., '79; Tanaka et al., '85).
Based on the bilaminar AChE staining pattern in the superior colliculus, both the superficial and intermediate layers may be sites for the termination of cholinergic afferent projections.
This study has determined the PPN and LDTN to be sources of the cholinergic projection to the intermediate gray layer.
Large injections of HRP in the superior colliculus, involving spread to the superficial layers, labelled neurons in the PPN, LDTN, and parabigeminal nucleus.
Injections confined to the superficial layers produced heavy labelling of the parabigeminal nucleus but only sparse labelling in the PPN and LDTN.

By contrast, in one experiment where the injection was centered in the intermediate and deep layers with minimal superficial layer involvement, there was virtually no retrograde neuronal labelling in the parabigeminal nucleus.
The laminar-specific projections of the parabigeminal nucleus to the superficial laver and the PPN to the intermediate layer have - .
The AChE staining pattern in the intermediate gray layer therefore may be attributable, at least in part, to a cholinergic projection arising from the PPN and LDTN.
The function associated with the AChE staining pattern in the superficial layers, however, is somewhat obscure.
Low levels of ChAT, relative to the intermediate gray layer, have been found in the superficial layers of the superior colliculus (Ross and Godfrey, '85).

In addition to the previously defined brainstem cholinergic cell groups Ch5 and Ch6, which correspond, at least in part, to the PPN and LDTN, respectively (Mesulam et al., '83, '841, ChAT-immunoreactive neurons recently have been observed in the parabigeminal nucleus with the designation as cholinergic cell group Ch8, and these neurons also have been labelled by retrograde transport of HRP from the superior colliculus (Mufson et al., '86).
This finding thus suggests the possibility of a cholinergic projection to the superficial layers of the superior colliculus that is different from the projection to the intermediate layer.
In the present study, the density of retrograde HRP labelling of neurons in the parabigeminal nucleus precluded assessment of whether most of these also were ChAT-immunoreactive.

The distribution of parabigeminal neurons labelled by retrograde transport of HRP from the superior colliculus, however, did not appear to be coextensive with the region of this nucleus that either displayed intense AChE staining (cf.
Fig. 3A,D) or contained neurons that exhibited only weak ChAT-immunoreactive staining compared to that of neurons in the PPN, LDTN, and cranial nerve motor nuclei.
As a result of this relatively weak staining, these neurons in the parabigeminal nucleus were not interpreted to be ChAT-immunoreactive.
These qualitatively disparate results, however, also may reflect differences in either the sensitivities of the antibodies used or the immunohistochemical procedures themselves.

In addition to a possible role in cholinergic mechanisms, the localization of AChE in the superficial and perhaps, to a certain extent, in the intermediate layers may be related to other functions of the enzyme such as hydrolysis of substance P or leuand met-enkephalin (Chubb et al., '80, '81, '83).
The latter have been demonstrated to have laminarspecific patterns of localization in the superior colliculus (Graybiel et al., '84).

In addition, substance P has been colocalized in approximately one-third of the ChAT-immunoreactive neurons in the PPN (Vincent et al., '83), although it is unknown whether these neurons project to the superior colliculus.
The projection from the LDTN to the superior colliculus, as demonstrated in the present study, confirms previous findings of an anterograde tracing study (Groenewegen and Van Dijk, '84).

In the rat, the LDTN also projects to other regions of the brain such as the substantia nigra, lateral geniculate nucleus, and the medial frontal cortex (MackeySim et al., '83; Groenewegen and Van Dijk, '84).
In addition, a cholinergic projection from both the PPN and LDTN to the interpeduncular nucleus and limbic telencephalon has been demonstrated (Woolf et al., '84; Woolf and Butcher, '85).

Indeed, the LDTN and PPN have many of the same efferent connections, including the thalamus and frontal cortex (Jones and Yang, '85), although clear differences are apparent in at least some of their efferent connections, notably in relation to the basal ganglia.

The projection from the PPN to the superior colliculus Dotentiallv reDresents another comuonent of the complex system b i which the basal ganglia may influence the-visuomotor functions of the superior colliculus (Fig. 7).

The extensive connections of the PPN with the basal ganglia include afferents from the neostriatum (Jackson and Crossman, '81a; Saper and Loewy, '82), the entopeduncular nucleus or its homologous medial pallidal segment (Nauta and Mehler, '66; Kim et al., '76; Hopkins, '77; Jackson and Crossman, '81a; Saper and Loewy, '82; Moon-Edley and Graybiel, '83; Rye et al., '85), the lateral pallidal segment (Hopkins, '77; Jackson and Crossman, '81a), the subthalamic nucleus (Nauta and Cole, '78; Graybiel and Ragsdale, '79; Carpenter et al., '81b; Jackson and Crossman, '81a,b; Saper and Loewy, '82; Moon-Edley and Graybiel, '83), the substantia nigra pars reticulata (sN~; Hopkins and ~ i sen, '76; Hopkins, '77; Nauta et al., '78; Beckstead et al., '79; Graybiel and Rags&+, '79; Jackson and Crossman, '81a; Beckstead and Frankfurter, '82; Saper and L ~ '82; Beckstead, '83; Moon-Edley and Graybiel, '83; Rye et al., '85), and possibly the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc; Hopkins and Niessen, '76; Beckstead & al., '79).
In addition, the PPN also receives afferents from the motor cortex (Graybiel and Ragsdale, '79; Moon-Edley and Graybiel, '83).

The efferents of the PpN indicate reciprocal connections with several basal ganglia structures such as the neostriatum (Saper and Loewy, '82; Parent et al., '83), the entopeduncular nucleus (Graybiel, '77, Graybiel and Ragsdale, '79; Carpenter et al., '81a; Saper and Loewy, '821, the lateral pallidal segment (Graybiel, '77; saper and L ~ '82), and the subthalamic nucleus (Graybiel, '77; Graybiel and Ragsdale, '79; Saper and Loev, '82; Mmn-Edley and Graybiel, '83; Sugimoto and Hattori, '84).
A more widesuread influence of the PPN mav be mediated bv efferent connections with the intralaminar and reticular nuclei of the thalamus (Sofroniew et al., '85).

Some of these connections have been confirmed electrophysiologically and indicate that the PPN receives an inhibitory input from the subthalamic nucleus and substantia nigra Wammond et al., '83; Noda and Oka, '84, '86) and has an excitatory effect on the same structures (Hammond et al., 83; Scarnati et al., '84).
The PPN also has excitatory synaptic connections with neurons in the entopeduncular nucleus and the globus pallidus (Gonya-Magee and Anderson, '83).

In addition to extrapyramidal motor-related structures, the PPN also projects to structures related to the visual system such as the superior colliculus, as demonstrated in the present study, and the lateral geniculate nucleus (Graybiel, '77; Moon-Edley and Graybiel, '83).
The basal ganglia is known to influence the visual system by means of its connections with the superior colliculus.

The SNr, considered a major outflow structure of the basal ganglia, has direct efferent projections to both the superior colliculus and PPN, which are to some extent by axon collaterals (Mifi et al., '70; Hopkins and Niessen, '76; Faull and Mehler, '78; Anderson and Yoshida, '80; Beckstead et al., '81; Niijima and Yoshida, '82; Beckstead, '83).
Although the SNr does not receive a direct projection from the PPN, it could be influenced indirectly by the neostriatum and subthalamic nucleus, both of which receive afferents from the PPN.
The neostriatum and subthalamic nucleus are also influenced by other structures by means of a complex loop system within the basal ganglia (see Graybiel and Ragsdale, '79).

While the inhibitory effect of SNr neurons on the superior co~liculus is well established (Chevalier et al., '84; Hikosaka and w~rtz, '85; Karabelas and Moschovakis, '85), the effect of the PPN on the neurons of the superior collicU h S is unknown.

Based on the evidence of an excitatory influence on the substantia nigra, subthalamic nucleus, entopeduncular nucleus, and the globus pallidus (GonyaMagee and Anderson, '83; Hammond et al., '83; Scarnati et al., '841, the synaptic effect of the PPN on the superior CO~liCU~US presumably is the same.

If so, the projections from the SNr and PPN could represent complementary systems of inhibitory and excitatory inputs to the superior c o ~ ~ l i ~ c from ~ l - ~ structures ~ that are functionally related to ganglia.
the Various extrapyramidal motor disorders are associated with ~ degenerative ~ , neUrOna1 changes in structures related to the basal ganglia.
For example, Huntington's and Parkinson's diseases are characterized by cell loss in the striat U and substantia nigra, respectively.
There is evidence that the PPN also may be involved in diseases of the basal ganglia.
Cell loss has been observed in this region in encephalitic Parkinson's disease (Papez, '42).

The PI" has also been implicated as the source of resting tremors associated with Parkinson's disease (Folkerts and Spiegel, '53; Poirer, '60; Aronson et al., '62; Kaelber, '63; Jasper and Bertrand, '66).

Oculomotor disturbances in Huntington's and Parkinson's ~ diseases ~ include ~ increased , saccadic latency, hypometric saccades, decreased velocity of saccades, and saccadic jerks (Leigh et al., '83; White et al., '83).

These deficits might be attributed to alteration of tonic nigrocollicular inhibition (Hikosaka and wurtz, '85) and may represent an imbalance between the SNr GABAergic inhibitory and PPN cholinergic excitatory inputs that converge in the intermediate layer ofthe superior COlliCUlUS.
